title: Thursday, 2nd February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:11 am
PM11:11am

Test

PM11:12am

Hi everyone

PM11:13am

Sorry for the tech snafu

11:12 am
PM11:13am

Not sure what the problem was

PM11:13am

But we seem to be sorted

PM11:13am

Best press on

11:13 am
PM11:13am

Before we go to the baby milk blockbuster

PM11:13am

And rather than a pic for today

PM11:13am

You get a pdf for today

11:13 am
PM11:13am

https://ftalphavil...tter-to-Yellen.pdf

PM11:14am

Read that

PM11:14am

(Trumps up -- arly)

11:14 am
PM11:14am

So I was beginning to think i was losing perspective

PM11:14am

That letter struck me as explosive

PM11:15am

But then reading up on the author I realised he had some form

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Patrick McHenry

PM11:16am

Trouble is, President Trump has shown a habit for treating people with extreme views and people who maybe should form policy

PM11:16am

It's damn scary

11:16 am
PM11:16am

The letter is amazing

PM11:16am

But have another par of this chap's prose

PM11:16am

We spent the night in the Green Zone, in the poolhouse of one of Saddam’s palaces. A little weird, I got to be honest with you. But I felt safe. And so in the morning, I got up early – not that I make this a great habit – but I went to the gym because I just couldn’t sleep and everything else. Well, sure enough, the guard wouldn’t let me in. Said I didn’t have the correct credentials. It’s 5:00 in the morning. I haven’t had sleep. I was not very happy with this two bit security guard. So you know, I said, “I want to see your supervisor.” Thirty minutes later, the supervisor wasn’t happy with me, they escort me back to my room. It happens. I guess I didn’t need to work out anyway.

11:16 am
PM11:17am

That's from about eight years ago

PM11:17am

As a member of congress visiting Iraq

PM11:17am

Offending that some "two bit security guard" won't let him use the gym

11:17 am
PM11:17am

People, eh?

undefined
PM11:18am

Between tech issues and loony financial news flow, I'm all over the place

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Oh no, now Ive started reading Albert

PM11:19am

The Donald Administration might be a neo-liberal nightmare, but stripping away some of his more controversial rhetoric on immigration, a lot of what he says on the economic front makes perfect sense to me.

BE11:19am

Omg smile

11:19 am
PM11:19am

closes pdf

undefined
PM11:19am

Shall we just discuss Reckitt?

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Yes, right, this is all a wee bit embarrassing.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,043, up 213 (+3.12%), High: 7,195, Low: 6,937, Volume: 2.36m
BE11:20am

There's been considerable noise quite a while that Reckitt was close to doing something big.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Mentioned it this Saturday past, in fact: https://www.ft.com...-9645-c9357a75844a

BE11:21am

There has also been considerable noise around Mead Johnson for, like, forever.

BE11:22am

As in, it was heavily rumoured to be in talks early last year with Nestle and Danone but those talks collapsed.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Collapsed in late January, early February-ish, before the story leaked about them bringing in Lazard to consider options.

BE11:23am

Since then we've had people telling us: "RECKITT IS PLANNING SOMETHING BIG!" And other people telling us "MEAD JOHNSON IS PLANNING SOMETHING BIG!"

BE11:23am

But we never added one plus one, because we're idiots.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Easily done

PM11:23am

(Please do Golly)

BE11:24am

Or rather, it's partly because we're idiots. It's also because this is entirely outside Reckitt's stated plan.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

It's not over-the-counter regulated drugs. It's baby milk.

BE11:24am

It's not a company where costs are easy to cut.

BE11:25am

It's not growth in emerging markets or whatever, because China is a baby milk bubble that's already deflating.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

(Which, to editorialise for a moment: good.)

BE11:25am

There are a lot of questions regarding strategy here.

BE11:25am

None particularly easy to answer.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Here's Citigroup.

BE11:26am

BE11:26am

11:26 am
PM11:26am

hmm

BE11:26am

(Sorry about the screenshots. Just making things easier for myself.)

BE11:26am

And Caz.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

With 14% accretion (on the basis of 5% synergies), the deal adds a new leg of growth in IMF – Nutrition is an adjacent category to OTC. That said, we would expect the market to view the potential deal with skepticism, given 1) questions on what Reckitt would bring to enhance Mead from a top-line standpoint, 2) cross selling synergies that may be tough to materialize and would require investments, 3) questions over the level of costs synergies and 4) uncertainties in the MT around China and the level of profitability in this market (have margins been rebased enough?). In conclusion, while the market has backed RB’s M&A track record in OTC, a lot of explanation and convincing would be needed to justify the deal (ROIC of 4.7% on the deal inc synergies).

BE11:27am

RB’s rationale to acquire OTC businesses in the past has been that being a consumer company it
can drive strong growth opportunities for these (OTC) businesses along with improvement in operating margin. MJN, however, already has high profitability (EBIT margin in 2016 at 24.8%, Ken Goldman expects 23.7% in 2017) and top-line growth opportunities have been under pressure in the category as China’s baby market bubble is in a phase of normalizing (China accounts for 40% of the category worldwide). We believe the issue of structural margin levels in China – i.e. have margins been rebased yet? – is one of the main risks to Mead along with potential for market share losses in the main US market where many of Mead’s WIC contracts are up for renewal. That said we note that Mead SG&A of 39.7% is well above RB’s 32%, an area where RB could implement its sharp cost focus to deliver cost synergies.

PM11:27am

There's quite a few questions there!

11:28 am
BE11:28am

As I say. Everyone seemed to be keen on the idea of Reckitt hanging around until Pfizer's consumer health side comes up for sale.

PM11:29am

Which would have fitted into the current structure

BE11:29am

This isn't that. It's far from that. And one has to wonder why Reckitt's not showing the patience of its investors.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

But baby milk

BE11:29am

Yeah, it's a problematic market. The Nestle boycotts are worth noting in passing here.

PM11:30am

Have they never heard of Patti Rundall????

11:30 am
PM11:30am

BE11:31am

?

PM11:31am

http://www.babymilkaction.org/donate

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Oh.

PM11:31am

So once I wrote a comment piece that was supportive of Nestle

PM11:31am

And baby milk, sort of

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Oh.

PM11:32am

The board of Nestle thought it was a good idea to project my piece across the stage at the Nestle AGM

PM11:32am

To stick it to the protesters

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Oh.

PM11:32am

I had to move to the FT to escape the protesters

PM11:32am

The Reckett baord have just ruined their lives

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Hm.

BE11:33am

There's still time for them to escape. There's always the possibility that Nestle doubles down here.

BE11:33am

Which leads us into the counterbid theory.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

"Possibly!" says the sellside.

BE11:33am

Caz, again.

BE11:33am

We recently wrote about Nestlé’s rumored interest in MJN. We flagged that, strategically, Nestlé would benefit from building up a leading position in the US Baby market though it may face potential antitrust hurdles in Mead's main markets of China and the USA. We would not expect Danone to take part in any counterbid given its ongoing involvement with WhiteWave.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

And BMO.

BE11:34am

The proposed price, which implies nearly 30% premium, and values MJN at 2017 P/E and EV/EBITDA multiples of 28x and 18x, likely will be welcomed by most investors, and perhaps even by management, given the company's recent operating performance, weak 2017 EPS guidance (signals third consecutive year of negative earnings growth), and 14% decline in the share price in the last three months.

BE11:34am

However, we wonder if Mead's board would take the offer on the table or whether it would (or even should) wait for a higher offer, given (1) MJN shares traded above $90 as recently as late July, and for an extended period in 2014/15 albeit with higher growth expectations. (2) There have been multiple news items (e.g., Bloomberg) about other potential bidders, including Danone and Nestle. Though these were never substantiated, Mead's pure-play exposure in an attractive category could make it a strategic target. (3) Other strategic buyers, such as Nestle (Not Rated), may be able to offer a higher price due to incremental cost/revenue synergy opportunities. While most acquirers could reduce Mead's G&A costs, Nestlé's large/global infant formula business and geographical overlap
with Mead likely creates a significant duplication in costs related to advertising/promotions, marketing, sales force, and R&D. Mead, alone, spends nearly $1.2 billion annually on these costs. Assuming a scaled formal player could generate $150-$250 million of incremental costs synergies relative to RB, and assuming a conservative 14x on incremental synergies could yield additional $10-$12 of value.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Is that enough on feeding babies? I mean, I'm simply not sure why Reckitt shares are up 3% on this.

PM11:36am

It probably is

PM11:37am

But really -- a counter bid by Nestle?

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Anti-trust anyone?

PM11:37am

Maybe corporates think they can rush stuff through amid the political chaos

PM11:37am

(You know Trump has pumped out five tweets just while we've been on air)

11:38 am
PM11:38am

(Yes, I now get instant notifications on my phone when he tweets)

BE11:38am

Hm.

11:11 am

PM11:39am

That's a chunky stake

in French Connection

Which is in one of those bankruptcy auctions

PM11:40am

11:40 am

(sixth Trump tweet)

BE11:41am

PM11:41am

Yeah, that was narrative

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Rebuild relationships with suppliers, refit stores to look less like Soviet-era jumble sales, etc.

BE11:42am

The idea that Ashley would use the company as his personal retail turnaround punting vehicle was was downplayed.

BE11:42am

But ...... well, 11% of French Connection doesn't suggest that. It suggests the opposite.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

It's Schroders' stake he's bought, incidentally.

BE11:43am

It had been second biggest shareholder. And Andy Brough wouldn't, one would have thought, been a seller to Ashley if he thought it was a platform for a bid.

PM11:44am

Thats a point

French Connection Group PLC (FCCN:LSE): Last: 39.85, up 0.0979 (+0.25%), High: 41.05, Low: 37.00, Volume: 225.62k

Trade went through at 33p yesterday. Shares spiked after it hit the tape.

There's a load of results, of varying interest.

BE11:46am

Vodafone's an India warning.

11:46 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 192.80, down 0.2 (-0.10%), High: 194.20, Low: 186.50, Volume: 41.48m
BE11:47am

....... Though I'm not sure it tells us much that wasn't already disclosed by the Idea merger proposal: India's tough.

PM11:47am

And always will be

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Saeed Bardar of Louis Capital has done some adding up. It's bleak stuff.

BE11:48am

INDIA WAS A DRAG - €11bn INVESTMENT OVER THE LAST 6 YEARS FOR AN OPERATING FCF RETURN OF LESS THAN €3.5BN and during this time a lot of management time and resources wasted on an ongoing court case related to the capital gains tax on the original acquisition in 2007 - While I commend Vodafone's management for making the right decision, no amount of spin will convince me of the original benefits of this acquisition (or ongoing benefits for that matter) or the fact that in my view a number of other assets remain under pressure (i.e. UK), that CAPEX numbers are too low and have to move up, that concerns on FCF remain, that it is wrong not to have Spectrum costs which are a cost of running the business included in FCF projections, and that the dividend cover remains under pressure.

BE11:48am

DIVIDEND HAS NOT BEEN COVERED SINCE 2010/11 - As evident from the table below Dividend has not been covered since 2010/11. It amazed me that telecom companies continue to argue that spectrum should not be included in FCF forecasts as they are one-offs and difficult to project. They are not one-offs as evident in the table below and they are not difficult to project as I do for every country later in this piece (see below). In total since 2010/11 after dividends and spectrum Vodafone has run A DEFICIT OF AROUND £13.1bn - ONLY ONE THING TO SAY - THANK GOODNESS FOR THE VERIZON STAKE SALE!

11:49 am
BE11:49am

He's gone to seller this morning. Unconvinced by the strategy of bundling out the worst performing bits of the business into JVs.

BE11:49am

No confidence that what's left can support the divi.

11:51 am

What else? There's M&B, I guess.

Mitchells & Butlers PLC (MAB:LSE): Last: 261.80, down 9.6 (-3.54%), High: 266.40, Low: 254.50, Volume: 251.41k
BE11:52am

Barclays a seller.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Blimey, it's slashed its price target

PM11:53am

220p from 375p

PM11:53am

That's some rethink

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Idea here is that M&B needs to chuck a lot of cash upgrading its own fleet rather than expanding it.

BE11:53am

So, cash generation deteriorates.

BE11:54am

Sector note. Summary goes like this:

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Ranking by Free Cash Flow - JDW is our preferred OW, M&B downgraded to UW. We turn our attention back to Free Cash Flow and capital allocation as the key metrics for our sector preferences, as investor concerns over debt risks subside. JD Wetherspoon is our favoured pub company (OW rated, PT raised to 1050p), and we upgrade FY17 EBIT forecasts by 4%. The company's Dec-17E Free Cash Flow yield of c10% (pre-new pub capex) is still amongst the highest in the sector. We are happy to ignore the optically high Dec-17E PE rating of 16.5x, and believe the company's change in capital allocation (fewer new builds and recent disposals) leaves more cash available for share buybacks. We downgrade Mitchells & Butlers to Underweight (PT 220p) from Equal Weight due to deteriorating Free Cash Flow. We expect capex of £200m in FY17 (vs depreciation of £117m), with the majority of capex being spent on the existing estate rather than new pubs. We no longer value the company using EV/EBITDA given the capital intensity and switch to EV/EBIT, using a multiple of 10.5x. At our Price Target, the company trades on a PE of just 6x which seems optically low, but this ignores the annual pension cash contributions of c£45m, as well as the mismatch between capex and depreciation. Given net income exceeds FCF, The FCF yield (pre-new pub capex) is just 5.2% at our PT, the lowest of the managed pubs and well below JDW (8.2% FCF yield at our PT).

BE11:55am

And on stock specific ..........

BE11:55am

Overweight – JD Wetherspoon and Greene King. Both generate sufficient FCF to fund their rollout, dividends and, in Greene King’s case, its debt amortisation. Wetherspoon is our preferred pub company. The P&L has been resilient in previous downturns, we consider it the most innovative retailer in this sub-sector, and its long-term focus has created value for shareholders. The relatively high FY17E PE of 16.5x does not deter us, as the company has the highest FCF yield (pre-new pub capex) out of the managed operators. Greene King has the best long-term track record in capital allocation (Figure 11), and we consider this more important than recent subdued trading.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Equal Weight – Enterprise Inns and Punch Taverns. We believe that tenanted pubs will trade well this year, with index-linked rents on a high proportion of the estate, and operational improvements after years of balance sheet focus. Both investment cases are similar, with value transferring from Debt to Equity. In the case of Punch we cut to EW from OW in light of the re-rating following the recent recommended bid at 180p.

BE11:56am

Underweight – Marston’s and Mitchells & Butlers. We have long held concerns over Marston’s increasing Net Debt (net cash outflows in 8 of the last 10 years, including a rights issue), which leaves the company exposed in the event of a shock to trading. Some investors and the company rightly point out that capex on new builds could be cut in the event of a downturn, creating Net Cash inflows, but we believe there are risks that this cannot be done quickly enough if demand slows. We downgrade Mitchells & Butlers to UW from EW on the basis that annual capex of c£200m means we now expect much weaker net cashflow, with new bank debt needed to fund securitisation amortisation. MAB’s FY17E PE of 7.4x looks low vs history, but this ignores the £572m actuarial pension deficit (which could rise once the March-16 actuarial pension valuation is announced), and the fact that it has the lowest FCF yield in the sector (pre-
new pub capex).

PM11:58am

12:01 pm

12:04 pm
